    wage setting
  • wage setting
      Current scene type
    • morning
      Log
    • old wage: 1.25 --> new wage: 1.25

[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Lucinda Mayfield has called for a strike, demanding that boss Josephine Blackwood rescind their decision to reduce wages.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] The peculiar frontier town of Dry Gulch, built on stilts above the floodplains, transforms into a bustling hub of riverboat traffic during the rainy season, drawing gamblers and merchants alike. But beneath the veneer of prosperity, a dark undercurrent of corruption and vice threatens to consume the town.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] The Silver Dollar Saloon, its swinging doors beckoning weary travelers, is a beacon of vice in a lawless land and a powder keg waiting to explode. Cattle barons and railroad men clash over whiskey and cards, their grudges as bitter as the liquor they drink.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] There is a remote settlement called Dry Gulch where disputes are settled not with law books but with lead. Each duel is a dance with death, a ritual of honor and revenge.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] The remote outpost at Dry Gulch was a critical junction for the railroad. Susannah Blackburn, a diligent station master, found herself in the middle of a deadly standoff when bandits took over the station, aiming to hijack a gold shipment. Using her knowledge of the schedules and the layout, she orchestrated a daring counterattack to reclaim the station.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Silas Redburn, a dedicated railroad construction cook, kept the workers fed and motivated through grueling hours. When a severe food shortage hit the camp, he embarked on a daring journey to secure supplies, risking his life to ensure the workers could continue their labor.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] As a fearless railcar repairer, Millicent Cartwright tackled the most dangerous jobs with skill and bravery. When a series of sabotages targeted the railcars, she worked tirelessly to repair the damage and catch those responsible, ensuring the railway's safety.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Working as a lineman, Augustus McCoy scaled the tallest telegraph poles to keep the lines of communication open. When a storm tore through the region, cutting off contact, he embarked on a perilous journey to repair the lines, battling both nature and time.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Wilhelmina Thatcher, a veteran brake operator, had a knack for stopping trains on a dime. During a routine trip through the Red Giant Mesa, a rockslide sent the train hurtling towards disaster. she sprang into action, using her skills to bring the train to a screeching halt, saving countless lives and becoming a hero in the process.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] As a water tank tender, Louisa Merriweather ensures the locomotives are always ready for their next journey. When a severe drought threatened the water supply, she ventures deep into the wilderness to find new sources, facing hostile terrain and wildlife to keep the trains running.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] As a skilled tracklayer, Cornelius Flint took pride in laying down the smoothest tracks in the territory. However, when a section of the track was repeatedly vandalized, he led a group of workers to guard the railway and catch the culprits.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Josephine Blackwood masterminded a scheme to undercut competitors by flooding the market with cheap, substandard materials. When rival rail lines collapsed, Prairie Firebird Railway swooped in to buy up the remnants at a fraction of their worth, expanding her empire further.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] To maintain control over the vast stretches of railroad, Josephine Blackwood established a network of spies and informants within her workforce. Any hint of dissent or rebellion was swiftly and ruthlessly crushed, often with public executions to serve as a warning to others.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Greed, they call it. But it was ambition, a hunger that couldn't be sated. Josephine Blackwood took what was theirs, by hook or by crook. The smaller railroads, the stubborn townsfolk who stood in her way, they were obstacles to be removed, nothing more.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Driven by an insatiable greed, Josephine Blackwood orchestrated hostile takeovers of smaller rail companies, consolidating power and expanding Prairie Firebird Railway's reach. her mercenaries, known for their brutal tactics, ensured compliance from resistant townsfolk and workers alike.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Word is Lucinda Mayfield's got a way with words, that she can spin a yarn so convincing it'll make you doubt your own eyes. Some say she's a liar, others say she's a prophet.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Some say Lucinda Mayfield's got a past darker than a coal mine, that she's running from something, or someone. But others say she's just trying to make a difference, no matter the cost.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Millicent Cartwright has sworn never to go back to Dry Gulch. The memories of a failed romance and the sting of public humiliation are too painful to bear. Only a desperate plea from someone she deeply cares about, or the promise of a chance to right a past wrong, might convince her to return.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Millicent witnessed Lucinda cowering in fear during a confrontation with a group of rowdy drunkards at the Silver Dollar Saloon. Lucinda, usually so quick with a sharp retort or a cunning plan, seemed utterly helpless, her eyes wide with terror. This unexpected display of weakness shattered Millicent's image of Lucinda as an unflappable force, leaving her feeling disappointed and disillusioned. A sliver of pity mixed with her disappointment, though, as she recognized a vulnerability in Lucinda that she hadn't seen before.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Millicent's unwavering determination, born from a deep-seated fear of failure, is her greatest strength, though she perceives it as a necessary burden. She mistakes her stubborn pride, which often prevents her from seeking help or admitting vulnerability, for strength.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Desperate for work after a fire destroyed her family's farm, Millicent took a job as a railcar repairer for Prairie Firebird Railway, hoping to earn enough to rebuild her life.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Millicent views Josephine Blackwood with a mixture of awe and resentment. She admires Blackwood's ruthless ambition and business acumen, but resents her coldheartedness and the fear she instills in her workers.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Millicent endures her job with Prairie Firebird Railway, seeing it solely as a means to an end. The work is grueling and the atmosphere oppressive, but it provides the income she needs to survive and, hopefully, one day rebuild her life.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Millicent believes Josephine Blackwood sees her workers as nothing more than cogs in a machine, disposable and replaceable. This belief stems from a specific incident where she witnessed Blackwood coldly dismiss a worker who was injured on the job, refusing to provide him with adequate medical attention and instead focusing on minimizing the disruption to the railway's schedule. The callous indifference displayed by Blackwood that day solidified Millicent's conviction that she is only concerned with profit, not the well-being of her employees.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] While Millicent admires Lucinda Mayfield's fiery spirit and outspokenness, she remains skeptical of organized labor movements. She fears that such efforts will only lead to further unrest and jeopardize her own precarious position.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Millicent is torn when it comes to Lucinda Mayfield. While she admires Lucinda's passion and dedication to the working class, she also remembers a time when Lucinda, in the midst of a heated speech about workers' rights, completely overlooked Millicent's pleas for help with a personal issue. This incident left Millicent feeling unseen and unimportant, casting doubt on Lucinda's genuine concern for individuals like her.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] What casual acquaintances remember about Millicent Cartwright is that she is a quiet and reserved woman, always focused on her work. She keeps to herself, rarely engaging in idle chatter or revealing much about her personal life. Her weathered hands and calloused palms speak volumes about her dedication to her craft as a railcar repairer. Some might notice a slight tremor in her hand when she's nervous, betraying a hidden vulnerability beneath her stoic exterior. She rarely speaks of her past, preferring to focus on the present and the tasks at hand. While she's not unfriendly, she doesn't go out of her way to make friends, content to remain on the periphery of social interactions. Overall, casual acquaintances would likely describe her as a competent and hardworking woman, but somewhat solitary and enigmatic.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Despite the dangerous and demanding nature of their work, railroad workers are paid a pittance. Many find themselves trapped in a cycle of debt, unable to save money or leave their jobs. The low wages mean that workers can barely afford basic necessities, let alone support their families back home.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Chinese and Irish workers, in particular, face severe discrimination and are often assigned the most dangerous and undesirable tasks. They are paid less than their white counterparts and subjected to verbal and physical abuse. This systemic racism creates tension within the workforce and makes conditions even more unbearable for minority groups.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] There's whispers in the bunkhouses that Lucinda Mayfield's got a secret stash of books, forbidden knowledge that could turn a man's head and make him question the natural order of things.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] There is a secretive vigilante group known as Scarlet Rider Outlaws who wear distinctive dusters and hide their faces behind masks. They operate outside the law to bring justice to areas where corruption has rendered official law enforcement ineffective.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] In the mountain passes, snow drifts pile high, burying men and machinery alike. Some are dug out, but others remain entombed, ghosts in the white expanse.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Workers often have to make do with substandard or poorly maintained tools and equipment. This not only makes their jobs more difficult but also increases the risk of accidents and injuries. The company's reluctance to invest in proper equipment puts an additional physical strain on the workers.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] What Millicent Cartwright remembers about Susannah Blackburn is that she's a quiet, reserved woman who keeps to herself. She rarely speaks unless spoken to, and when she does, her voice is soft and measured. Her face is etched with worry lines, hinting at the burdens she carries. She has a habit of twisting her wedding ring when she's anxious, a nervous tic that betrays her inner turmoil. Most people wouldn't describe her as particularly friendly, but they also wouldn't say she's unfriendly. She simply seems lost in her own world, a world of unspoken pain and unfulfilled dreams.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Yes, Silas Redburn has known hunger many times throughout his life. As a child growing up in poverty, food was often scarce, and he learned to endure long periods without a proper meal. This experience instilled in him a deep-seated fear of starvation, which drives his relentless pursuit of security and stability for himself and his family.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Seeking steady work and a chance to build a better life for his family, Silas Redburn answered a call for laborers on the expanding Prairie Firebird Railway.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Silas Redburn views Josephine Blackwood with a mixture of fear and grudging respect. He recognizes her ambition and ruthlessness, but also sees her as a necessary evil in a harsh and unforgiving world.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Silas Redburn endures his job with Prairie Firebird Railway, viewing it solely as a means to an end. He finds no satisfaction in the grueling labor, but he pushes through, driven by the desperate need to provide for his family.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Silas Redburn believes Josephine Blackwood sees workers like him as expendable cogs in her machine, nothing more than tools to be used and discarded. He recalls a time when several workers were injured in a blasting accident, and Blackwood showed little concern for their well-being, prioritizing the resumption of work over their recovery.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Silas Redburn is wary of the labor movement and Lucinda Mayfield, viewing them as troublemakers who threaten the fragile stability he has fought so hard to achieve. He fears that their actions could lead to unrest and jeopardize his job, the one thing standing between his family and destitution.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Silas Redburn is unsure about Lucinda Mayfield's true intentions. While he has seen her speak passionately about workers' rights, he also remembers a time when she rallied workers to strike, resulting in a violent confrontation with company guards. This incident left him fearful of her influence and doubtful of her genuine concern for the common man.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] What casual acquaintances remember about Silas Redburn is that he's a hard worker, always eager to prove his worth. He presents himself as a gruff, no-nonsense man, quick to anger but with a hidden vulnerability. He often talks about his family, his desire to provide for them, and his fear of losing them. Some might find his constant boasting about his strength and resilience a bit tiresome, while others might see it as a mask for his underlying insecurities. Overall, casual acquaintances would likely describe him as a tough but ultimately decent man, struggling to make his way in a harsh world.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] The workers' camp is a breeding ground for disease and vermin. Tents are overcrowded, with men sleeping shoulder to shoulder on dirt floors. The lack of proper sanitation facilities leads to outbreaks of dysentery, cholera, and other infectious diseases.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] The company store is a spider's web, ensnaring men in a cycle of debt. The prices are high, the wages low, and the escape elusive.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] The foreman cracks his whip, his words sharp as the lash. Obedience is demanded, dissent punished with a swift and brutal hand.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] What Silas Redburn remembers about Susannah Blackburn is that she's a quiet, reserved woman who keeps to herself. She rarely speaks unless spoken to, and when she does, her voice is soft and measured. Her face is etched with worry lines, hinting at the burdens she carries. She has a habit of twisting her wedding ring when she's anxious, a nervous tic that betrays her inner turmoil. Most people wouldn't describe her as particularly friendly, but they also wouldn't say she's unfriendly. She simply seems lost in her own world, a world of unspoken pain and unfulfilled dreams.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] What Silas Redburn remembers about Millicent Cartwright is that she is a quiet and reserved woman, always focused on her work. Her weathered hands and calloused palms speak volumes about her dedication to her craft as a railcar repairer. While she's not unfriendly, she doesn't go out of her way to make friends, content to remain on the periphery of social interactions. Overall, casual acquaintances would likely describe her as a competent and hardworking woman, but somewhat solitary and enigmatic.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] The rhythmic clang of the telegraph, a constant reminder of connection to the world beyond the dusty plains, brings Susannah a strange peace. The steady clicks and whirs soothe her simmering resentment, offering a temporary escape from the stifling reality of her life. But this solace is fleeting, for the telegraph also serves as a conduit for news of the outside world, a world where her dreams of a better life seem increasingly out of reach.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] A group of workers consider their options after Boss Josephine Blackwood cut their pay from 2.75 coin to 1.25 coin.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah's unwavering determination to provide for her family fuels her strength, a force that drives her through grueling days and sleepless nights. However, she mistakes her stubborn refusal to acknowledge her own needs and desires for strength, believing that vulnerability is a weakness to be suppressed.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Desperate for work and a means to support her family, Susannah took a job as a telegraph operator for Prairie Firebird Railway, hoping the steady paycheck would offer a path to a better life.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah views Josephine Blackwood with a mixture of fear and resentment. She admires Blackwood's ruthlessness and ambition, recognizing a kindred spirit in their shared drive for survival, but she also resents the woman's cold-heartedness and the exploitative nature of her business practices.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah endures her job with Prairie Firebird Railway, viewing it as a necessary evil to provide for her family. The work is monotonous and thankless, but the steady paycheck keeps a roof over their heads and food on the table.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah doubts that Josephine Blackwood cares about anyone but herself. She remembers a time when a worker was injured on the job, and Blackwood refused to pay for his medical expenses, deeming him expendable. The callous indifference in Blackwood's eyes that day solidified Susannah's belief that to Blackwood, workers are simply cogs in a machine, easily replaceable.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah is torn when it comes to the labor movement and Lucinda Mayfield. She understands the workers' plight and sympathizes with their struggles, but she's also afraid of the repercussions of getting involved. Lucinda's fiery speeches and radical ideas both intrigue and frighten her. She admires Mayfield's courage but fears the violence that often accompanies such movements.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah is unsure about Lucinda Mayfield's true intentions. While Mayfield's words resonate with Susannah's own frustrations, she's witnessed firsthand how quickly idealism can turn into something dangerous. She remembers a time when Mayfield rallied workers to strike, only for the protest to turn violent, leaving several people injured. The fear in their eyes, the blood staining the dusty ground, made Susannah question whether Mayfield's cause was worth the cost.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] What casual acquaintances remember about Susannah Blackburn is that she's a quiet, reserved woman who keeps to herself. She rarely speaks unless spoken to, and when she does, her voice is soft and measured. Her face is etched with worry lines, hinting at the burdens she carries. She has a habit of twisting her wedding ring when she's anxious, a nervous tic that betrays her inner turmoil. Most people wouldn't describe her as particularly friendly, but they also wouldn't say she's unfriendly. She simply seems lost in her own world, a world of unspoken pain and unfulfilled dreams.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Workers are routinely exposed to harmful substances like lead, asbestos, and coal dust without any protective gear. Some workers who were previousy healthy have developed respiratory diseases.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] The company-provided meals are often insufficient and of low quality. Workers subsist on a monotonous diet of beans, salted meat, and hardtack, leading to malnutrition and vitamin deficiencies. Fresh fruits and vegetables are a rare luxury in the remote work camps.

[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] The most beautiful sight Susannah has ever seen was a sunrise over the Painted Desert, a breathtaking tapestry of colors splashed across the vast expanse. But at the time, she barely registered its beauty, her mind consumed by the weight of her responsibilities and the gnawing feeling of being trapped.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Silas Redburn's unwavering determination to provide for his family is a hidden strength, fueling his resilience in the face of adversity. He mistakes his blustering persona and need for control as strength, unaware that his vulnerability and fear of loss are what truly drive him.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Josephine Blackwood's men, they are wolves, teeth bared and eyes gleaming with the thrill of the hunt. They enforce her will, their loyalty bought and paid for with blood money. Towns burned, lives snuffed out, all in the name of progress.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Lucinda Mayfield would like nothing more than to bring down Josephine Blackwood and all the corrupt bosses of Prairie Firebird Railway. Such an achievement would cement her reputation in the labor movement.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Driven by a desire to escape the suffocating mines and see the vastness of the West, Lucinda Mayfield joined Prairie Firebird Railway as a surveyor. she quickly rose through the ranks, her sharp mind and natural leadership abilities catching the attention of her superiors.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Josephine Blackwood heard the reports of poor conditions experienced by railroad construction workers but attitude is that such things are the price of progress, the cost of carving civilization out of this unforgiving land. believes that every life lost is a tally mark on the ledger, a sacrifice on the altar of ambition. What is the price of a man's life when weighed against the riches that await? Every penny pinched, every corner cut, adds another dollar to the war chest. Let the fools cry about safety and comfort, in the end, their suffering will be forgotten, their bones buried beneath the rail ties that bind this nation together.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] What Josephine Blackwood remembers about Susannah Blackburn is that she's a quiet, reserved woman who keeps to herself. She rarely speaks unless spoken to, and when she does, her voice is soft and measured. Her face is etched with worry lines, hinting at the burdens she carries. She has a habit of twisting her wedding ring when she's anxious, a nervous tic that betrays her inner turmoil. Most people wouldn't describe her as particularly friendly, but they also wouldn't say she's unfriendly. She simply seems lost in her own world, a world of unspoken pain and unfulfilled dreams.

[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Josephine Blackwood holds court in gilded halls, surrounded by the sycophants and leeches who flocked to her wealth. Deals struck, alliances forged, all to further her grand design. The world is her chessboard, and the pieces move at her command.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Politicians, they were puppets dancing on Josephine Blackwood's strings. she greased their palms with gold and silver, and in return, they passed laws that paved the way for her dominion. The law was a weapon, just as sharp as any pistol.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] In the coal mines, Lucinda Mayfield had witnessed the power of strikes and the formation of early labor unions. Though initially skeptical, she saw how collective action could lead to improved conditions and a sense of solidarity among the workers.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Lucinda Mayfield's upbringing instilled in her a strong sense of fairness and justice. she witnessed the harsh treatment of the railroad workers and recognized the parallels to her own experiences in the mines.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Lucinda Mayfield draws inspiration from figures like William H. Sylvis, the founder of the National Labor Union, and the writings of Henry George, who proposed radical land reforms to address economic inequality and most recently published an article titled 'What the Railroad Will Bring Us' in October of 1868.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Lucinda Mayfield knows the strike will be a gamble, a roll of the dice against the might of the railroad. But the stakes are too high to back down. The time has come for the workers to rise up, to demand their due

[03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] As Susannah Blackburn discreetly observed the saloon patrons, she gained a better understanding of the workers' grievances and the level of support Lucinda Mayfield had.
[03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] Summary of a conversation between Millicent Cartwright, Susannah Blackburn, Lucinda Mayfield. The women are expressing their shared exhaustion and desire for fairer treatment.
[03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] Millicent Cartwright told Lucinda and Susannah about the toll the hard labor is taking on her body and how she worries about providing for her family, prompting Lucinda to offer words of encouragement and support, strengthening their bond.
[03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] Summary of a conversation between Millicent Cartwright, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood. Millicent and Susannah express their dissatisfaction with their working conditions, while Josephine dismisses their concerns.
[03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] As Silas Redburn surveyed the saloon, taking note of the patrons' demeanors, he noticed a group of workers huddled together, whispering angrily.
[03 Oct 1868 20:00:30] Summary of a conversation between Millicent Cartwright, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood, Lucinda Mayfield. The women are debating whether or not they deserve respect for their hard work.
